Award.AwardTitle: Natural selection and genes determining higher arterial saturation in Peruvian Quechua

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Worldwide, several human populations may have adapted to high altitude (HA) based on long-term residence in mountainous areas above 3,000 meters. In the Andean region of South America, Quechua natives have lived at altitudes averaging 4,000 meters for at least the past 6,000 years. The specific aim of this project will be to collect genetic and physiological trait data on Quechua (n=600) and to test for association between previously identified genetic markers and high arterial hemoglobin-oxygen saturation (SaO2). The results of this project could provide an answer to the long-standing question of whether Andean populations are genetically adapted to high altitude. The Quechua sample will include sub-samples, born and raised at HA or at sea-level. This will allow evaluation of developmental effects as these may also determine higher SaO2. A sample of n=300 lowlanders will serve as a control group.
Six thousand years is a conservative time-depth estimate for Quechua residence at HA and is long enough for Quechua to have experienced natural selection i.e., genetic adaptation. Selection could have favored traits enabling survival under the challenge of chronically low oxygen levels, such as traits related to O2 transport capacity. Apart from genetics, growth and development at HA may exhibit developmental adaptation. For example, lung-size is enhanced in persons born and raised at HA. The current project will test both genetic and developmental hypotheses to explain SaO2 of Peruvian Quechua. The SaO2 is a major determinant of the amount of oxygen in the blood, and Quechua are especially impressive in maintaining high SaO2 during exercise at HA. In previous work, the current research team used a whole-genome approach to identify genomic regions in Quechua that showed strong a priori evidence of natural selection. This genome scan used a dense panel of single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) genetic markers, and provided evidence of natural selection in several genes of the hypoxia inducible factor (HIF) pathway. HIF is a central regulator that controls downstream genes involved in maintaining cellular oxygen levels.
The project is an international collaboration with Peruvian researchers and includes student involvement in both the USA and Peru.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Quechua populations residing in the Andean region of South America may have experienced past natural selection in response to the challenge of life at high altitude.  Indeed, previous work among Quechua and related populations has revealed a number of traits that likely have adaptive physiological benefit.  For example, Peruvian Quechua have larger lung volumes compared to lowland populations.  Our previous NSF work suggested that natural selection had operated on the Quechua genome and also revealed several genetic variants associated with physiological traits related to Quechua breathing patterns and the amount of oxygen carried in their blood (the arterial oxygen saturation).  In order to test hypotheses of genetic adaptation to high altitude we proposed the creation of a large data set integrating genetic and physiological data on Peruvian Quechua participants as well as on a US referent population.

The data collection was completed in August 2015 after a 4-year effort. We now have DNA and physiological data on 303 Peruvian Quechua residing in Cerro de Pasco, Peru (4,300 m), 301 Peruvian Quechua residing in Lima, Peru (0 m), and 148 US participants from Syracuse, New York (116 m). Thus, the overall completed data set includes ~750 individuals and constitutes a unique resource for future genetic analysis that is not likely to be replicated soon. At present, we are processing the physiological data and completing the genotyping of all samples. The latter is via the Axiom Biobank array which features approximately 610,000 genetic markers.

To date, several abstracts have been published or submitted from this project. Several preliminary analyses have been conducted and these have been informative regarding the overall utility and promise of the data set.  As an example, we have now identified a genetic marker in the EGLN1 gene that is associated with the arterial oxygen saturation and hypoxic ventilatory response (HVR) of Peruvians.  EGLN1 is a gene that is involved in the formation of hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF) alpha, which plays an important role in maintaining cellular oxygen levels.  Our previous NSF supported work also identified EGLN1 as a target of selection in the Andes, and the work of others has strongly implicated EGLN1 as a genetic factor in the adaptation of Tibetan populations to high altitude.  In our Andean sample, the higher frequency variant of this EGLN1 marker is at 96% frequency within the population. Individuals with two copies of this variant, which is the majority of the sample, have 2-3 percentage point higher arterial oxygen saturation and 50% higher HVR.  These findings need to be confirmed, but we anticipate our major results will be published in a year. We are encouraged that our initial analyses point strongly to at least one gene of significant interest in the area of high-altitude biology.
